thinking.disposable_income: South Chicago is a lower-income community with median income of $43,936, significantly below Chicago's average. About 55.6% of households earn less than $50,000 annually, indicating limited disposable income for most residents
thinking.discretionary_consumption: With high percentage of low-income households, residents have limited discretionary spending capacity. Higher sales taxes or transportation costs would significantly impact household budgets and reduce spending on other essential needs
thinking.accessibility: 31.6% of households have no vehicle, and 23.7% rely on transit for commuting. While 58.2% drive alone, the high proportion of transit-dependent residents suggests need for affordable and efficient public transit
thinking.decision_rationale: 1. Prioritized policies with lower transit fares ($0.75) given high transit dependency and low incomes. 2. Favored lower sales tax (0.5-1.0%) to protect discretionary spending power. 3. Supported moderate driving fees ($0.50) to improve transit service without overly burdening drivers. 4. Balanced travel time improvements with cost impacts. 5. Considered that many residents must drive but also need reliable transit options
